Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was
What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain
Comments_List: I significantly improved my understanding of statistical inference.
Probability theory, estimation theory; more R skills

Knowledge of how statistics relates to data, and how that relates to the world. Skills on how to manipulate sample data and how to construct estimators. Knowledge of how to evaluate estimators: unbiased, efficient, consistent.
Some knowledge of statistics, regression, R coding
None.

I learned statistical inference with a focus on theoretical implications and derivation. Apart from some of the practical skills, this course was very helpful in understanding what we usually do when we use some commands in statistical softwares.
TA office hours were very limited given the high difficulty of the course.

Strengths: Not sure
Weaknesses: The prof is brilliant but not that great at translating that brilliance to pedagogy.  Sometimes I feel like he just didn't know how to explain things simply. Sometimes section felt absolutely useless.

The course begins with the real world and a macro overview which really helps me see what I am learning about. The weekly section to help with psets is a good idea. I have a sense that Fredrik did try to squeeze a fair amount of content into the class.

Strength: Fredrik gives great background to the lessons; the p-sets were challenging but not overwhelming (in terms of both length and difficulty)
Weakness: such a long class period! I have a feeling like I'm not extremely confident about what I learned, but I'm not quite sure why I feel that way.

While I think the overall structure and approach of the course is good, it was very unclear to follow what we were doing in class at times and why we were doing it. So in general more connections to the overall structure/big picture/goals really would have helped.

I feel like we departured  from the book without a reliable source to read at few points in the semester and that really made it hard to understand what is going on. This could be mitigated if we had slides to go to for reference.

This course was painfully basic. The material was presented in probably the worst possible way. Out of all statistics and quantitative methods courses I have taken, this has been the worst and lowest level of all. The professor's teaching style is difficult to follow or take anything away from. The TAs were completely useless, and often either did not show up to their office hours, or provided objectively false information.
This course is well-organized overall.
I would recommend this course to another student who already has a strong statistics background.
Yes, because it's required.
Very useful and methods are extremely relevant, almost 'necessary', to understanding and doing much of contemporary social science research.
Yea I would. It was mostly clear and a good level of challenging. Was a useful combination of statistics and R coding.
No. This class was a waste of time in many ways.
Yes, because the approach this course takes is theoretical. This helps us understand what we actually do in our practical statistical analysis.
